levels.label: entry
levels.description: Reading and writing numbers to 1,000,000 using a place value chart, identifying the value of each digit.
levels.example_task: Write in digits: two million, three hundred and four thousand and fifty. What is the value of the 3?
levels.example_response: 2,304,050. The 3 is worth 300,000 (three hundred thousand).
common_errors: Omitting a zero placeholder (writing 234,050 or 2,340,50)
Saying the 3 is worth 3,000 (misidentifying the column)

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Reading, writing and ordering numbers to 10,000,000, including numbers with multiple zero placeholders.
levels.example_task: Order these from smallest to largest: 4,006,050; 4,060,500; 4,600,005; 4,005,060.
common_errors: Comparing by looking at the final digits rather than column by column from the left
Misreading numbers with zeros: confusing 4,006,050 with 4,060,500

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Identifying the value of any digit in numbers up to 10,000,000, partitioning flexibly, and applying the ones-thousands-millions grouping pattern.
levels.example_task: In 7,482,319, what is the value of the 4? Partition 5,600,000 in two different ways.
common_errors: Saying the 4 is worth 40,000 or 4,000,000
Only knowing the standard partition

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Explaining the multiplicative structure of the place value system across non-adjacent columns and using it to reason about equivalences involving millions.
levels.example_task: How many thousands are there in 10,000,000? Explain why 3,500,000 is the same as 35 hundred-thousands.
levels.example_response: 10,000,000 ÷ 1,000 = 10,000 thousands. 3,500,000 = 35 × 100,000, so it is 35 hundred-thousands. Each column is 10 times the one to its right, so moving two columns left multiplies by 100.
common_errors: Computing 10,000,000 ÷ 1,000 as 1,000 instead of 10,000
Being unable to explain the multiplicative relationship between non-adjacent columns

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Rounding whole numbers to the nearest 10, 100, 1,000 and 10,000 (consolidating Year 5 skills).
levels.example_task: Round 456,789 to the nearest 10,000.
levels.example_response: 460,000. The thousands digit is 6 (≥ 5), so round up.
common_errors: Looking at the wrong digit (checking the hundreds digit instead of the thousands)
Rounding to 450,000 (rounding down when the decider is ≥ 5)

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Rounding to the nearest 100,000 and 1,000,000, and rounding decimals to the nearest whole number and to 1 decimal place.
levels.example_task: Round 3.456 to 1 decimal place. Round 2,750,000 to the nearest million.
levels.example_response: 3.456 rounds to 3.5 (the hundredths digit 5 rounds up). 2,750,000 rounds to 3,000,000.
common_errors: Rounding 3.456 to 3.4 (truncating instead of rounding up at 5)
Not knowing which digit to examine when rounding decimals

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Rounding any number to any degree of accuracy and selecting appropriate rounding for estimation and context.
levels.example_task: A charity raised £3,847,291. Round this to the nearest million for a headline and to the nearest £100,000 for a report.
levels.example_response: Headline: approximately £4,000,000. Report: approximately £3,800,000.
common_errors: Using the same rounding for both contexts without considering purpose
Rounding £3,847,291 to the nearest £100,000 as £3,900,000 (looking at wrong digit)

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Counting through zero in both directions on a number line, reading negative numbers in the context of temperature.
levels.example_task: The temperature is –3°C. It rises by 7 degrees. What is the new temperature? Use the number line.
common_errors: Computing –3 + 7 = –10 (adding the magnitudes with the wrong sign)
Stopping at 0 and saying the answer is 0

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Calculating intervals across zero between a negative and a positive number without a number line.
levels.example_task: The temperature fell from 5°C to –8°C overnight. What was the temperature drop?
levels.example_response: From 5 to 0 is 5 degrees. From 0 to –8 is 8 degrees. Total drop: 5 + 8 = 13 degrees.
common_errors: Computing 8 – 5 = 3 (subtracting absolute values instead of bridging through zero)
Computing 5 – (–8) = 5 – 8 = –3 (mishandling the double negative)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Solving multi-step problems with negative numbers in context, including ordering negative numbers and calculating with them fluently.
levels.example_task: At 6 am the temperature was –5°C. By noon it was 8°C. By midnight it had dropped 14°C from noon. What was the midnight temperature? Order all three temperatures.
levels.example_response: Midnight: 8 – 14 = –6°C. Order (coldest to warmest): –6°C, –5°C, 8°C.
common_errors: Ordering as –5, –6, 8 (thinking –5 < –6 because 5 < 6)
Computing 8 – 14 as 6 instead of –6

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Multiplying a 3-digit number by a 2-digit number using the grid method as a bridge to the formal layout.
levels.example_task: Use the grid method: 245 × 36.
common_errors: Missing a cell in the grid (especially the middle cells)
Errors in the mental multiplication of partial products

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Using the formal long multiplication layout for 4-digit × 2-digit with correct alignment and the zero placeholder.
levels.example_task: Use long multiplication: 3,456 × 28.
common_errors: Forgetting the zero placeholder in the second row
Carrying errors across four columns in a single row

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Reliably computing any 4-digit × 2-digit multiplication, checking with estimation, and solving multi-step problems.
levels.example_task: A factory makes 2,475 items per day for 24 days. How many items in total? Estimate first.
common_errors: Not estimating and therefore not catching order-of-magnitude errors
Getting the multiplication correct but misinterpreting the word problem

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Dividing a 3-digit number by a 2-digit divisor from the times tables (e.g. 13, 15, 25) using the chunking method as a bridge.
levels.example_task: Use chunking: 375 ÷ 25.
common_errors: Choosing very small chunks (subtracting 25 repeatedly, which is slow and error-prone)
Not keeping track of how many chunks have been subtracted

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Using the formal long division layout for 4-digit ÷ 2-digit, following the estimate-multiply-subtract-bring-down cycle.
levels.example_task: Use long division: 4,368 ÷ 14.
levels.example_response: 43 ÷ 14 = 3 (14×3=42, remainder 1). Bring down 6: 16 ÷ 14 = 1 (14×1=14, remainder 2). Bring down 8: 28 ÷ 14 = 2. Answer: 312.
common_errors: Losing place value (writing quotient digits in the wrong column)
Writing 0 when the partial dividend is smaller than the divisor but forgetting to bring down the next digit

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Completing long division for 4-digit ÷ 2-digit and interpreting remainders as whole numbers, fractions or decimals according to context.
levels.example_task: A 2,350 cm ribbon is cut into 16 equal pieces. How long is each piece? Give your answer as a decimal.
common_errors: Writing '146 remainder 14' without converting to the decimal as requested
Not knowing how to continue long division past the decimal point

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Evaluating expressions with brackets first, recognising that brackets override left-to-right order.
levels.example_task: Work out (3 + 4) × 5.
common_errors: Computing 3 + 4 × 5 = 3 + 20 = 23 (ignoring the brackets)
Working left to right: 3 + 4 = 7, then not completing the multiplication

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Applying BODMAS/BIDMAS: evaluating multiplication and division before addition and subtraction.
common_errors: Working left to right: 12 + 8 = 20, × 3 = 60, – 4 = 56, ÷ 2 = 28
Computing multiplication first but forgetting to compute division before addition

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Evaluating multi-step expressions with brackets and mixed operations, and inserting brackets to make a given expression equal a target value.
levels.example_task: Insert one pair of brackets to make this true: 6 + 2 × 5 – 1 = 14.
common_errors: Inserting brackets randomly without evaluating the result
Not understanding how brackets change the order of operations

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Placing brackets in different positions within the same expression to produce very different results, and explaining why the order of operations causes the difference.
levels.example_task: Place brackets in 48 ÷ 2 × 3 + 1 to make it equal 96. Then place brackets differently to make it equal 6. Explain why the same numbers and operations give such different answers.
levels.example_response: For 96: 48 ÷ 2 × (3 + 1) = 24 × 4 = 96. The ÷ and × are done left to right, so 48 ÷ 2 = 24 first, then 24 × 4 = 96. For 6: 48 ÷ (2 × (3 + 1)) = 48 ÷ (2 × 4) = 48 ÷ 8 = 6. The inner brackets force 3 + 1 = 4 first, then the outer brackets force 2 × 4 = 8 before the division. In the first expression we divide then multiply (making the result larger); in the second we multiply first then divide into a bigger number (making the result smaller).
common_errors: Not seeing that 48 ÷ 2 × 4 ≠ 48 ÷ (2 × 4) — confusing left-to-right evaluation with grouped evaluation
Being unable to explain WHY the answers differ, only computing the results mechanically

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Finding all factors of a number up to 50 by systematic trial, and identifying whether it is prime.
levels.example_task: Find all factors of 36. Is 36 prime?
levels.example_response: Factors: 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 9, 12, 18, 36. Not prime (more than 2 factors).
common_errors: Missing factor pairs in the middle (e.g. missing 4 and 9)
Saying 36 is prime because it is a square number

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Finding common factors and common multiples of two numbers, identifying the HCF and LCM.
levels.example_task: Find the HCF of 24 and 36. Find the LCM of 6 and 8.
common_errors: Confusing HCF and LCM (using the LCM when asked for HCF)
Not listing factors systematically and missing common factors

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Using HCF to simplify fractions and LCM to find common denominators, and identifying primes up to 100 using divisibility tests.
levels.example_task: Simplify 48/60 using the HCF. Is 91 prime? Explain how you checked.
levels.example_response: HCF of 48 and 60: factors of 48 include 12, factors of 60 include 12. HCF = 12. 48/60 = 4/5. 91: not divisible by 2,3,5. 91 ÷ 7 = 13. So 91 = 7 × 13, not prime.
common_errors: Simplifying in multiple steps (48/60 → 24/30 → 12/15 → 4/5) rather than using HCF directly
Saying 91 is prime because it is odd, not ending in 0 or 5 (missing the factor 7)

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Simplifying fractions by dividing numerator and denominator by a common factor.
levels.example_task: Simplify 8/12.
levels.example_response: 8/12 = 4/6 = 2/3 (dividing by 2 twice) or 8/12 = 2/3 (dividing by 4, the HCF).
common_errors: Dividing only the numerator (getting 4/12 or 2/12)
Leaving the fraction in a partially simplified state (4/6 instead of 2/3)

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Comparing fractions by converting to a common denominator, including mixed numbers and improper fractions.
levels.example_task: Which is larger, 5/8 or 7/12?
common_errors: Comparing numerators without a common denominator (5 < 7 so 5/8 < 7/12)
Finding a common denominator but converting one fraction incorrectly

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Ordering a set of fractions, decimals and mixed numbers by converting to a common form, and simplifying complex fractions.
levels.example_task: Order from smallest to largest: 3/4, 0.7, 2/3, 0.72.
common_errors: Not converting 2/3 accurately (writing 0.67 instead of 0.666...)
Placing 0.7 and 0.72 in the wrong order (0.7 = 0.70 < 0.72)

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Adding and subtracting fractions with the same denominator, including mixed numbers.
levels.example_task: Work out 2 3/7 + 1 5/7.
common_errors: Adding numerators and denominators: 3/7 + 5/7 = 8/14
Forgetting to convert 8/7 to a mixed number and carry the extra whole

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Adding and subtracting fractions with different denominators by finding a common denominator.
levels.example_task: Work out 5/6 – 2/9.
common_errors: Using 54 as common denominator (6 × 9) instead of 18 (LCM) — not wrong but less efficient
Converting the fractions but making a multiplication error

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Adding and subtracting mixed numbers with different denominators, simplifying results, in problem contexts.
levels.example_task: A recipe uses 2 1/3 cups of flour and 1 3/4 cups of sugar. How much more flour than sugar? Simplify.
common_errors: Subtracting 4/12 – 9/12 and getting a negative fraction without borrowing
Not simplifying: 7/12 is already in simplest form, but pupils may not check

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Multiplying two proper fractions using the rule: multiply numerators, multiply denominators.
levels.example_task: Work out 2/3 × 4/5.
common_errors: Finding a common denominator first (as if adding) and then multiplying
Multiplying numerator by numerator but adding denominators (8/8)

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Dividing a fraction by a whole number by multiplying the denominator.
levels.example_task: Work out 3/4 ÷ 2.
common_errors: Dividing the numerator: 3/4 ÷ 2 = 1.5/4 (conceptually valid but procedurally messy)
Multiplying instead of dividing: 3/4 × 2 = 6/4

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Multiplying proper fractions with simplification (cross-cancellation), dividing fractions by whole numbers, and understanding that multiplying proper fractions gives a smaller result.
levels.example_task: Work out 3/8 × 4/9 using cross-cancellation. Explain why the answer is smaller than both fractions.
levels.example_response: Cross-cancel: 3 and 9 share factor 3 (3→1, 9→3). 4 and 8 share factor 4 (4→1, 8→2). So 1/2 × 1/3 = 1/6. The answer is smaller because you are taking a fraction of a fraction — a part of a part is smaller than either part.
common_errors: Not cross-cancelling and getting 12/72, then struggling to simplify
Being unable to explain why the product is smaller than either factor

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Knowing the key fraction-decimal-percentage equivalences: 1/2 = 0.5 = 50%, 1/4 = 0.25 = 25%, 1/10 = 0.1 = 10%.
levels.example_task: Write 3/4 as a decimal and a percentage.
common_errors: Writing 3/4 = 0.34 (using digits of the fraction as the decimal)
Knowing 1/4 = 25% but not connecting 3/4 = 3 × 25% = 75%

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Converting between fractions, decimals and percentages including eighths, fifths and thirds.
levels.example_task: Write 3/8 as a decimal. Write 0.2 as a fraction in simplest form. What percentage is 2/5?
common_errors: Not knowing 1/8 = 0.125 and therefore unable to derive 3/8 = 0.375
Writing 2/5 = 20% (dividing 2 by 5 and getting 0.4 but then writing 0.4%)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Converting any fraction, decimal or percentage and selecting the most useful form for a given context.
levels.example_task: A shop reduces prices by 1/3. Is this more or less than a 30% discount? Show your working.
levels.example_response: 1/3 = 33.3...% ≈ 33.3%. This is more than 30%. So a 1/3 discount is better for the customer.
common_errors: Writing 1/3 = 0.3 = 30% (rounding without noting it is a recurring decimal)
Not being able to convert 1/3 to a percentage accurately

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Ordering and comparing a mixture of fractions, decimals and percentages by converting to a common form, and justifying which form is most efficient for a given comparison.
levels.example_task: Put these in order from smallest to largest: 0.375, 2/5, 37%, 3/8. Explain which form you used and why.
levels.example_response: Convert to decimals: 0.375, 2/5 = 0.4, 37% = 0.37, 3/8 = 0.375. Order: 37% (0.37), then 0.375 and 3/8 (equal, both 0.375), then 2/5 (0.4). I used decimals because they are easiest to compare digit by digit. Fractions would need a common denominator of 200, which is harder.
common_errors: Converting 37% to 3.7 or 0.037 instead of 0.37
Not noticing that 0.375 and 3/8 are equal and treating them as different values

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Sharing a quantity in a simple ratio using the 'one part' method with concrete or pictorial support.
levels.example_task: Share 20 sweets between Ali and Ben in the ratio 3:2. How many does each person get?
levels.example_response: Total parts: 3 + 2 = 5. One part = 20 ÷ 5 = 4. Ali gets 3 × 4 = 12. Ben gets 2 × 4 = 8.
common_errors: Dividing 20 by 3 and 20 by 2 separately (getting 6.67 and 10)
Not finding the total number of parts first

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Solving proportion problems using the unitary method or scale factor, including simple recipes and scaling.
levels.example_task: A recipe for 4 people uses 300g flour. How much flour for 6 people?
levels.example_response: For 1 person: 300 ÷ 4 = 75g. For 6 people: 75 × 6 = 450g.
common_errors: Adding 2 people worth of flour by adding 2 × 75 = 150 to 300 = 450 (correct result, but additive reasoning can fail in harder cases)
Using additive reasoning: 6 is 2 more than 4, so add 2 × 50 = 100g more (wrong)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Solving ratio and proportion problems involving missing values, including percentage contexts, using multiplicative reasoning.
levels.example_task: In a class, the ratio of boys to girls is 3:5. There are 15 girls. How many children are in the class altogether?
levels.example_response: Girls represent 5 parts. 5 parts = 15, so 1 part = 3. Boys = 3 parts = 9. Total: 15 + 9 = 24.
common_errors: Adding 3 to 15 instead of finding the multiplier (saying 18 children)
Not finding the value of one part before scaling

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Solving multi-step ratio problems where the ratio must be inferred from context, or where a change in one quantity requires reasoning about the effect on the ratio.
levels.example_task: Purple paint is made by mixing red and blue in the ratio 3:5. Sam has 600 ml of purple paint. He adds 150 ml more red paint. What is the new ratio of red to blue? Give your answer in its simplest form.
levels.example_response: Original: 3 + 5 = 8 parts. One part = 600 ÷ 8 = 75 ml. Red = 3 × 75 = 225 ml. Blue = 5 × 75 = 375 ml. After adding red: 225 + 150 = 375 ml red. Blue stays at 375 ml. New ratio = 375:375 = 1:1.
common_errors: Adding 150 ml to the total and re-splitting in the original ratio (not understanding only red changed)
Simplifying 375:375 as 3:3 instead of 1:1

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Understanding that a letter represents an unknown number and evaluating simple expressions by substitution.
levels.example_task: If n = 5, what is 3n + 2?
common_errors: Reading 3n as 35 (concatenating instead of multiplying)
Not knowing that 3n means 3 × n

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Writing algebraic expressions from word descriptions and evaluating expressions with two operations.
levels.example_task: Write an expression for 'twice a number, subtract 7'. If the number is 12, evaluate.
common_errors: Writing n2 – 7 instead of 2n – 7
Applying operations in the wrong order (subtracting 7 first then doubling)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Using formulae in context, substituting values into multi-variable expressions, and forming expressions from problems.
levels.example_task: The perimeter of a rectangle is P = 2(l + w). Find P when l = 8 and w = 5. A pizza costs £p. Write an expression for the cost of 3 pizzas and a £2 delivery charge.
common_errors: Computing 2 × 8 + 5 = 21 instead of 2(8 + 5) = 26 (forgetting to evaluate the bracket first)
Writing 3p + 2 as 3p2 or 32p

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Continuing a linear sequence given the first few terms and describing the rule as 'add n each time'.
levels.example_task: Continue this sequence: 3, 7, 11, 15, ?, ?. What is the rule?
levels.example_response: 19, 23. The rule is add 4 each time.
common_errors: Adding the wrong amount (adding 3 instead of 4)
Not being able to state the common difference explicitly

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Generating terms of a sequence from a rule and finding pairs of values that satisfy a two-variable equation.
levels.example_task: Find all pairs of positive whole numbers where a + b = 8.
common_errors: Missing symmetric pairs (listing 1+7 but not 7+1, if both are required)
Not working systematically and missing pairs in the middle

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Describing linear sequences algebraically, enumerating solutions to two-variable equations, and solving problems involving sequences.
levels.example_task: A sequence starts at 5 and adds 3 each time. Is 50 in the sequence? Explain.
levels.example_response: Terms: 5, 8, 11, 14... Each term is 3n + 2 (where n starts at 1). For 50: 3n + 2 = 50, 3n = 48, n = 16. Yes, 50 is the 16th term.
common_errors: Checking by listing all terms up to 50 (correct but slow)
Setting up the equation correctly but making an arithmetic error

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Finding the area of a rectangle using length × width (consolidating Year 4/5), and understanding that a triangle is half a rectangle.
levels.example_task: A rectangle is 8 cm by 5 cm. What is its area? If you cut it diagonally, what is the area of each triangle?
levels.example_response: Rectangle area: 8 × 5 = 40 cm². Each triangle: 40 ÷ 2 = 20 cm².
common_errors: Adding instead of multiplying (8 + 5 = 13 cm²)
Not understanding why the triangle is half the rectangle

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Applying the formula A = 1/2 × b × h for triangles and A = b × h for parallelograms, using perpendicular height.
levels.example_task: A triangle has base 12 cm and perpendicular height 7 cm. What is its area?
common_errors: Using the slant height instead of the perpendicular height
Forgetting to halve (computing 12 × 7 = 84 cm²)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Finding areas of triangles and parallelograms in any orientation, and solving problems where a dimension must be calculated.
levels.example_task: A parallelogram has area 72 cm² and base 9 cm. What is its perpendicular height?
common_errors: Not rearranging the formula (guessing rather than dividing)
Confusing the formula for a parallelogram with the formula for a triangle

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Calculating the volume of a cube or cuboid by counting unit cubes or using V = l × w × h.
levels.example_task: A cuboid is 6 cm long, 4 cm wide and 3 cm tall. What is its volume?
common_errors: Computing 6 × 4 = 24 and stopping (finding area of the base, not volume)
Writing cm² instead of cm³

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Solving problems where one dimension of a cuboid must be found given the volume, and comparing volumes of different shapes.
levels.example_task: A cuboid has volume 240 cm³. Its length is 10 cm and width is 6 cm. Find the height.
common_errors: Dividing by only one dimension (240 ÷ 10 = 24, then saying h = 24)
Not rearranging the formula correctly

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Estimating and calculating volumes of cubes and cuboids in appropriate units, converting between cm³ and m³ where needed, and solving multi-step problems.
levels.example_task: A swimming pool is 25 m long, 10 m wide and 1.5 m deep. What is its volume in m³? How many litres is this? (1 m³ = 1000 litres)
common_errors: Using the wrong unit conversion (1 m³ = 100 litres instead of 1000)
Not multiplying correctly with the decimal dimension (25 × 10 × 1.5 = 350 instead of 375)

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Using the fact that angles on a straight line sum to 180° and angles at a point sum to 360° to find a single missing angle.
levels.example_task: Three angles meet at a point: 120°, 150° and ?°. Find the missing angle.
common_errors: Using 180° instead of 360° for angles at a point
Adding the two known angles incorrectly

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Using vertically opposite angles and angles in triangles/quadrilaterals to find missing angles.
levels.example_task: Two straight lines cross. One angle is 35°. Find the other three angles.
levels.example_response: Vertically opposite: 35°. Adjacent angles: 180° – 35° = 145° (each). The four angles are 35°, 145°, 35°, 145°.
common_errors: Not recognising vertically opposite angles are equal
Using 360° – 35° = 325° and dividing by 3

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Finding interior angles of regular polygons using the sum formula (n-2) × 180° and combining multiple angle facts in multi-step problems.
levels.example_task: What is the interior angle of a regular hexagon? A triangle is drawn inside — find the base angles if the apex angle matches one interior angle of the hexagon.
levels.example_response: Hexagon angle sum: (6-2) × 180 = 720°. Each interior angle: 720 ÷ 6 = 120°. Triangle with apex 120°: base angles = (180 – 120) ÷ 2 = 30° each.
common_errors: Not dividing by the number of sides after finding the angle sum for a regular polygon

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Drawing a circle with a compass of a given radius and labelling the centre, radius and diameter.
levels.example_task: Draw a circle with radius 4 cm. Label the centre, a radius and a diameter.
levels.example_response: [Draws circle with compass set to 4 cm. Labels centre point, a line from centre to circumference as 'radius = 4 cm', and a line through the centre as 'diameter = 8 cm']
common_errors: Drawing a circle with diameter 4 cm instead of radius 4 cm
Not placing the compass point on the centre

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Using the relationship d = 2r to solve problems involving radius and diameter, and identifying other parts of a circle.
levels.example_task: A circle has diameter 14 cm. What is its radius? Name the line from A to B that passes through the centre.
levels.example_response: Radius = 14 ÷ 2 = 7 cm. A line from A to B through the centre is a diameter.
common_errors: Multiplying instead of dividing (radius = 28 cm)
Confusing a chord (doesn't pass through centre) with a diameter (does)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Solving multi-step problems involving circles, explaining the difference between radius, diameter, circumference, chord and arc.
levels.example_task: A wheel has radius 30 cm. What is its diameter? If two wheels are placed side by side touching, what is the total width?
levels.example_response: Diameter = 2 × 30 = 60 cm. Two wheels side by side: 60 + 60 = 120 cm = 1.2 m.
common_errors: Using radius instead of diameter for the width of one wheel (getting 60 cm total)
Not converting to metres when appropriate

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Plotting and reading coordinates in the first quadrant (positive x and y), consolidating Year 4/5 skills.
levels.example_task: Plot the points (2, 5), (6, 5), (6, 1) and (2, 1). What shape do they make?
levels.example_response: [Plots all four points] They make a rectangle.
common_errors: Reversing x and y (plotting (5, 2) instead of (2, 5))
Miscounting gridlines

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Plotting and reading coordinates in all four quadrants, including negative values.
levels.example_task: Plot (–3, 4) and (2, –1). Which quadrant is each point in?
levels.example_response: (–3, 4) is in quadrant II (negative x, positive y). (2, –1) is in quadrant IV (positive x, negative y).
common_errors: Plotting (–3, 4) in quadrant IV instead of quadrant II (getting the axes confused)
Ignoring the negative sign and plotting in quadrant I

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Using coordinates in all four quadrants to describe transformations and solve geometric problems.
levels.example_task: A shape has vertices at (1, 2), (4, 2), (4, 5). Reflect it in the y-axis. What are the new coordinates?
levels.example_response: (–1, 2), (–4, 2), (–4, 5). Reflection in the y-axis changes the sign of the x-coordinate.
common_errors: Changing the y-coordinate instead of the x-coordinate
Reflecting in the x-axis by mistake (getting (1, –2), (4, –2), (4, –5))

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Reading a simple pie chart where sectors are labelled with fractions or percentages.
levels.example_task: This pie chart shows favourite sports. The football sector is labelled 50%. If 40 children were asked, how many chose football?
levels.example_response: 50% of 40 = 20 children.
common_errors: Reading the angle (180°) as the number of children
Not knowing how to find 50% of 40

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Constructing a pie chart by calculating the angle for each sector: angle = (frequency ÷ total) × 360°.
levels.example_task: Draw a pie chart for: Red 10, Blue 15, Green 5, Yellow 6. Total = 36.
common_errors: Forgetting to multiply by 360 (using the fraction as the angle)
Angles not summing to 360° due to calculation errors

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Interpreting pie charts to find missing values and comparing pie charts that represent different-sized groups.
levels.example_task: In a pie chart, the 'swimming' sector is 90°. If 48 children were surveyed, how many chose swimming? Can you compare this pie chart directly with one from a survey of 60 children?
levels.example_response: 90° out of 360° = 1/4. 1/4 of 48 = 12 children chose swimming. You cannot compare the two pie charts directly by looking at sector size because they represent different totals — you need to calculate the actual numbers.
common_errors: Saying 90 children chose swimming (reading the angle as the frequency)
Comparing sectors from different pie charts as if they represent the same totals

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Finding the mean of a small data set by adding all values and dividing by the count.
levels.example_task: Find the mean of: 4, 7, 9, 8, 2.
common_errors: Adding incorrectly
Dividing by the wrong number (e.g. by the range or by the largest value)

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Working backwards from the mean to find a missing value or total, and understanding the 'levelling' interpretation.
levels.example_task: Five children have a mean score of 8. Four of the scores are 6, 9, 10, 7. What is the fifth score?
levels.example_response: Total must be 5 × 8 = 40. Known total: 6 + 9 + 10 + 7 = 32. Fifth score: 40 – 32 = 8.
common_errors: Not knowing to multiply the mean by the count to get the total
Subtracting incorrectly (40 – 32 = 12)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Using the mean to compare two data sets and understanding that the mean may not be a value in the data set.
levels.example_task: Group A scores: 5, 8, 7, 6, 9. Group B scores: 4, 10, 6, 8. Which group performed better on average?
levels.example_response: Group A mean: 35 ÷ 5 = 7. Group B mean: 28 ÷ 4 = 7. Both groups have the same mean, but Group B has more spread.
common_errors: Comparing totals (35 vs 28) instead of means
Not recognising that the same mean can come from very different data distributions

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Counting faces, edges and vertices of common 3-D shapes by handling physical models.
levels.example_task: How many faces, edges and vertices does a triangular prism have?
levels.example_response: 5 faces (2 triangles + 3 rectangles), 9 edges, 6 vertices.
common_errors: Miscounting edges (the most common error — there are 9, not 6 or 8)
Confusing faces with edges

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Recognising nets of cubes, cuboids and triangular prisms, and predicting which nets will fold into a given shape.
levels.example_task: Which of these nets will fold to make a cube? [Shows 3 net candidates, one valid]
levels.example_response: [Identifies the valid net — the one where no more than 4 squares are in a row and the arrangement allows all faces to fold without overlap]
common_errors: Accepting a net where faces would overlap when folded
Not checking by mentally folding each face

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Describing 3-D shapes by their properties, matching shapes to their nets, and explaining relationships (e.g. Euler's formula informally).
levels.example_task: A shape has 5 vertices, 8 edges and 5 faces. Name it. Check: is it true that faces + vertices = edges + 2?
levels.example_response: Square-based pyramid (5 vertices, 8 edges, 5 faces). Check: 5 + 5 = 10, 8 + 2 = 10. Yes, Euler's formula holds.
common_errors: Confusing a square-based pyramid with a triangular prism
Not being able to verify the relationship between F, V and E

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Translating a shape on a coordinate grid by adding or subtracting from each vertex's coordinates.
levels.example_task: Translate the triangle with vertices (1, 3), (4, 3), (4, 6) by 3 right and 2 down.
common_errors: Subtracting from x instead of adding for 'right'
Moving different vertices by different amounts

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Reflecting shapes in the x-axis and y-axis on a four-quadrant grid, stating the coordinate rule for each reflection.
levels.example_task: Reflect the point (–2, 5) in the x-axis. What is the rule for reflecting in the x-axis?
levels.example_response: (–2, –5). The rule: when reflecting in the x-axis, the x-coordinate stays the same and the y-coordinate changes sign.
common_errors: Changing the x-coordinate instead of the y-coordinate
Reflecting in the y-axis by mistake

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Describing transformations precisely using coordinates, combining translations and reflections, and identifying which transformation maps one shape to another.
levels.example_task: Shape A has vertices (1, 2), (3, 2), (3, 5). Shape B has vertices (–1, –2), (–3, –2), (–3, –5). What single transformation maps A to B?
levels.example_response: Reflection in the origin (or a rotation of 180° about the origin). Each coordinate (x, y) becomes (–x, –y).
common_errors: Saying it is a translation (it is not — the shape is not simply shifted)
Describing two separate reflections instead of identifying the combined transformation

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Using a single angle fact to find one missing angle in a simple configuration.
levels.example_task: An angle on a straight line is 72°. What is the other angle?
common_errors: Using 360° instead of 180°
Subtracting from 90° (confusing with complementary angles)

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Combining two angle facts in a two-step problem, stating the fact used at each step.
levels.example_task: In a diagram, angle A = 55° is on a straight line with angle B. Angle B is an angle in a triangle with angles C = 40° and D. Find angle D.
levels.example_response: Angle B = 180° – 55° = 125° (angles on a straight line). Angle D = 180° – 125° – 40° = 15° (angles in a triangle).
common_errors: Not stating which angle fact is used at each step
Using the wrong fact for the configuration

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Solving multi-step angle problems requiring three or more facts, with clear deductive reasoning chains.
levels.example_task: Two straight lines cross. One angle is 70°. An equilateral triangle is drawn using one of the other angles. Find all angles in the diagram.
levels.example_response: Vertically opposite: 70°. Adjacent angles: 110° each. The equilateral triangle has all angles 60°. The remaining angles at the intersection within the triangle's base: 110° – 60° = 50°.
common_errors: Not identifying all the angles in the diagram systematically
Making arithmetic errors in the chain of deductions

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Placing events on a probability scale from 'impossible' to 'certain' using everyday language.
levels.example_task: Place these on the scale: rolling a 7 on a normal die, getting heads on a coin, the sun rising tomorrow.
levels.example_response: Rolling a 7: impossible. Getting heads: even chance. Sun rising: certain.
common_errors: Saying rolling a 7 is 'unlikely' rather than 'impossible'
Not understanding the difference between 'unlikely' and 'impossible'

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Listing all outcomes of a simple experiment and expressing probability as a fraction.
levels.example_task: A bag has 3 red and 5 blue counters. What is the probability of picking a red counter?
levels.example_response: Total counters: 3 + 5 = 8. P(red) = 3/8.
common_errors: Writing P(red) = 3/5 (using number of blue as denominator instead of total)
Saying the probability is 3 (not expressing as a fraction)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Calculating probabilities of single events as fractions, decimals or percentages, and understanding that all probabilities sum to 1.
levels.example_task: A spinner has sections: red (120°), blue (90°), green (150°). What is the probability of landing on blue? Express as a fraction, decimal and percentage.
common_errors: Not dividing by 360 (writing P = 90)
Not checking all probabilities sum to 1: 120/360 + 90/360 + 150/360 = 360/360 = 1

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Calculating the range of a data set and describing it as a measure of spread.
levels.example_task: Find the range of: 4, 11, 7, 3, 9.
levels.example_response: Range = 11 – 3 = 8. The data is spread over 8 units.
common_errors: Computing 11 + 3 = 14 instead of 11 – 3
Not ordering the data first and subtracting two adjacent values instead

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Comparing two data sets using both a measure of average and a measure of spread.
levels.example_task: Team A scores: 3, 5, 4, 6, 2. Team B scores: 1, 8, 3, 7, 1. Compare using mean and range.
levels.example_response: Team A: mean = 4, range = 4. Team B: mean = 4, range = 7. Same average, but Team B is more spread out — their scores are less consistent.
common_errors: Comparing only the means and concluding the teams are equal
Not interpreting the range in context (just stating numbers without explanation)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Describing distributions using language of clusters, gaps and spread, and making justified comparisons between data sets.
levels.example_task: Class A test scores: 45, 67, 68, 70, 71, 72, 95. Describe the distribution. Is the mean a good representative value?
levels.example_response: Most scores cluster between 67 and 72. There are two outliers: 45 (low) and 95 (high). Mean = 488/7 ≈ 69.7. The mean is reasonably representative because it is in the cluster, but the two outliers pull it slightly. The median (70) might be more representative.
common_errors: Not identifying the cluster or the outliers
Stating the mean without considering whether it represents the data well

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Finding the mode of a data set by identifying the most frequently occurring value.
levels.example_task: Find the mode of: 3, 5, 7, 3, 9, 3, 5.
levels.example_response: The mode is 3 because it appears 3 times, more than any other value.
common_errors: Choosing the largest value (9) instead of the most frequent
Choosing the middle value (confusing mode with median)

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Finding the median by ordering data and locating the middle value, including with an even count.
levels.example_task: Find the median of: 8, 3, 11, 5, 7, 2.
levels.example_response: Ordered: 2, 3, 5, 7, 8, 11. Even count (6 values): median is the mean of the 3rd and 4th values = (5 + 7) ÷ 2 = 6.
common_errors: Not ordering the data first (picking the 3rd value from the unordered list)
With an even count, choosing one of the two middle values instead of averaging them

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Explaining when each average (mean, median, mode) is most appropriate and selecting the best one for a given data set.
levels.example_task: Shoe sizes in a class: 4, 4, 5, 5, 5, 5, 6, 6, 12. Which average best describes the typical shoe size? Why?
levels.example_response: Mode = 5 (most common). Median = 5. Mean = 52/9 ≈ 5.8. The mean is pulled up by the outlier (12). The mode or median (both 5) better represent the typical shoe size.
common_errors: Always choosing the mean without considering outliers
Not knowing that the mode is most useful for categorical data and the median resists outliers

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Reading data from a bar chart with a clear scale, answering 'how many' questions.
levels.example_task: This bar chart shows favourite pets. How many children chose fish?
levels.example_response: 8 children chose fish. [Reads from the top of the 'fish' bar to the y-axis]
common_errors: Reading the bar height inaccurately when it falls between gridlines
Confusing the x and y axes

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Interpreting line graphs (including interpolation), reading pie charts, and constructing bar charts and tables from data.
levels.example_task: Construct a bar chart from: Apples 12, Bananas 8, Cherries 15, Dates 5. Choose an appropriate scale.
levels.example_response: [Draws bar chart with y-axis going up in 2s from 0 to 16, bars at correct heights, labelled axes and title]
common_errors: Choosing a scale that doesn't fit the data (e.g. going up in 1s when the highest value is 15)
Drawing bars of unequal width

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Choosing the appropriate chart type for different data, identifying misleading features in given charts, and drawing conclusions from data.
levels.example_task: A newspaper chart shows sales rising dramatically, but the y-axis starts at 995 instead of 0. Why is this misleading?
levels.example_response: Starting the y-axis at 995 exaggerates the visual difference between bars. A rise from 998 to 1002 looks like a doubling when the y-axis starts at 995, but it is actually a tiny change relative to the total.
common_errors: Not noticing that the y-axis does not start at zero
Not understanding why a truncated axis makes differences appear larger

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Recalling multiplication facts to 12 × 12 and their related division facts with automaticity.
levels.example_task: Answer as fast as you can: 7 × 8, 9 × 6, 132 ÷ 11.
common_errors: Hesitating on 7 × 8 (the most commonly misremembered fact)
Needing to derive 132 ÷ 11 rather than knowing 11 × 12 = 132

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Selecting and applying efficient mental and written strategies for calculations with integers, decimals and fractions.
levels.example_task: Work out 0.6 × 7 mentally. Work out 3/5 of 45.
common_errors: Computing 0.6 × 7 = 0.42 (dividing by 100 instead of 10)
Computing 3/5 of 45 as 45 ÷ 3 = 15 (dividing by the numerator instead of the denominator)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Applying fluent number skills to multi-step problems, choosing the most efficient method for each step.
levels.example_task: A shop sells pens at £0.35 each. How much for 24 pens? What change from £10?
common_errors: Not converting between pounds and pence correctly
Making errors in the multi-step mental calculation

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Explaining what they did and why in a single-step calculation using mathematical vocabulary.
levels.example_task: Explain why you added 37 and 28 to solve the problem about apples.
levels.example_response: I added because the problem said 'altogether', which means combining two groups. 37 + 28 = 65 apples altogether.
common_errors: Describing steps without explaining why ('I added them' rather than 'I added because the problem asked for the total')
Using non-mathematical language

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Using examples and counter-examples to investigate whether a mathematical statement is always, sometimes or never true.
levels.example_task: Is this always, sometimes or never true: 'Multiplying two numbers gives a bigger answer'?
levels.example_response: Sometimes true. True: 3 × 4 = 12 (bigger than both). False: 0.5 × 6 = 3 (smaller than 6). Also false: 0 × 5 = 0 (not bigger than 5). So it depends on the numbers.
common_errors: Saying 'always true' based on whole number examples only
Not considering fractions, decimals or zero as counter-examples

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Constructing a chain of logical reasoning to prove or disprove a conjecture, distinguishing proof from demonstration.
levels.example_task: Prove that the sum of three consecutive numbers is always a multiple of 3.
levels.example_response: Let the three consecutive numbers be n, n+1, n+2. Their sum = n + (n+1) + (n+2) = 3n + 3 = 3(n+1). Since 3(n+1) is 3 times a whole number, it is always a multiple of 3.
common_errors: Checking only specific examples (1+2+3=6, 4+5+6=15) without proving it for all cases
Not understanding why checking examples is not a proof

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Identifying what a word problem is asking and selecting the correct operation.
levels.example_task: A pack has 8 biscuits. I need 50 biscuits. How many packs do I need? What operation will you use?
levels.example_response: Division. 50 ÷ 8 = 6 remainder 2. I need 7 packs (round up because I need at least 50).
common_errors: Answering '6 remainder 2' without rounding up in context
Using multiplication instead of division

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Solving two-step problems by identifying the steps needed, selecting methods and checking the answer is reasonable.
levels.example_task: Cinema tickets cost £7.50. A family of 4 goes. They also buy 2 buckets of popcorn at £4.25 each. What is the total cost?
common_errors: Only computing one step (tickets or popcorn but not both)
Adding 7.50 + 4.25 and multiplying by 6 (mixing the quantities)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Solving multi-step problems involving mixed operations across different mathematical domains, with systematic working and checking.
levels.example_task: A rectangular garden is 12 m by 8 m. A circular pond (radius 2 m) is in the middle. Fencing costs £15 per metre. Grass seed costs £3 per m². How much does it cost to fence the perimeter and seed the remaining garden (not the pond)?
levels.example_response: Perimeter: 2(12+8) = 40 m. Fencing: 40 × £15 = £600. Garden area: 12 × 8 = 96 m². Pond area ≈ π × 2² ≈ 12.57 m². Grass area ≈ 96 – 12.57 = 83.43 m². Seed cost ≈ 83.43 × £3 = £250.29. Total ≈ £850.29.
common_errors: Forgetting to subtract the pond area from the garden area
Computing the perimeter incorrectly or confusing perimeter with area

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Solving unfamiliar problems that require selecting and combining knowledge from multiple domains, reasoning about which information is relevant, and evaluating whether an exact or approximate answer is appropriate.
levels.example_task: A school hall is 20 m long and 15 m wide. 240 children need to sit on the floor for assembly. Each child needs a space 60 cm × 60 cm. Will they all fit? If 30 more children arrive, the head teacher says 'Squeeze up — everyone take 50 cm × 50 cm.' Is this enough? Show all working.
levels.example_response: Hall area: 20 × 15 = 300 m². Child space: 0.6 × 0.6 = 0.36 m². Max children: 300 ÷ 0.36 = 833. 240 < 833, so yes, easily. With 270 children at 0.5 × 0.5 = 0.25 m²: need 270 × 0.25 = 67.5 m². 67.5 < 300, so yes, plenty of room. But in practice, rows need aisles and a stage takes some space — so the real capacity is lower. An estimate of roughly half the hall being usable (150 m²) still gives 150 ÷ 0.25 = 600, which is more than 270.
common_errors: Not converting cm to m before computing area (using 60 × 60 = 3,600 m² instead of 0.36 m²)
Computing the space needed but not comparing it to the space available
